course.title: Introduction to Advertising and Public Relations

notes.div: ADPR 151 is open to non-College of Journalism and Mass Communications majors.

description.div: Fundamental concepts and processes underlying integrated marketing communications in a global market place. The disciplineâ€™s historical roots and current role of professionals.

notes.div: 12 hours max special topics hours at all levels (100, 200, 300, 400) per degree. ADPR 191 may be repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different.

description.div: Topics vary each term.

prerequisite.div: College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources (CASNR): completion of all CASNR core communications course requirements.

description.div: Concepts and techniques of public relations. Skills and theory for relating to government, corporate, and other agricultural public audiences.

course.title: Strategic Writing for Advertising and Public Relations

prerequisite.div: ADPR 151 Introduction to Advertising and Public Relations

description.div: Advertising and public relations writing styles and techniques to develop effective, goal-oriented communications designed for diverse audiences, tactics and media. This course spans objective news-style writing to digital storytelling, persuasive ad copywriting and promotional direct marketing.

course.title: Strategy Development for Advertising and Public Relations

notes.div: Writing assignments require incorporation of research and strategy development, culminating in a creative brief.

description.div: Examine client problems and possible solutions and develop and evaluate strategies and tactics for promotional communications.

notes.div: 12 hours max special topics hours at all levels (100, 200, 300, 400) per degree. May be repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different.

description.div: Topics vary each term.

The core of any great advertisement is its concept. This course is for copywriters to find that big idea then execute it by developing copy that effectively promotes the brand. Copywriters will have to write long copy, short copy, scripts for television and radio, and copy for interactive media.

Learn agency processes and business fundamentals. Work as junior member of one or more teams to conduct research and evaluate the findings, develop and present integrated marketing communications strategy and creative materials for a multimedia advertising and public relations campaign needed by a client.

Graphics and design of advertising. Principles and techniques of typography, layout and design, computer graphics, and production methods. Develop strategies and design ads for various media using industry-standard graphic design programs.

notes.div: Requires interview process and submission of portfolio.

description.div: Conduct research and evaluate the findings to develop and present an integrated marketing communications strategy and creative materials for a nationally competitive advertising and public relations campaign for a national client.
Examines the role of an advertising agency account planner in developing strategies in the form of creative briefs based on insights from both primary and secondary research research.

notes.div: ADPRÂ 360 assignments include evaluating, selecting, and planning the use of media.

description.div: The principles and practices of planning, evaluating, and selecting a variety of traditional and non-traditional media in a local and national context. Marketing-driven strategic approaches to understand how media fits into an integrated communication system. Integrating information from a variety of resources and applying basic numerical and statistical concepts that build the foundation for strategic media planning.

notes.div: 12 hours max special topics hours at all levels (100, 200, 300, 400) per degree. ADPR 391 may be repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different.

description.div: Topics vary each term.

course.title: Issues Management and Crisis Communications in Agriculture

prerequisite.div: Junior standing. College of Journalism and Mass Communications: Junior standing; ADPR 283.

description.div: Fundamental components of issues management and crisis communications. Learning experiences in agriculture and natural resources that provide an understanding of issues facing the respective field of study.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing and nine hours selected from 300- and 400-level ADPR courses and/or ADPR 207; permission required.

notes.div: Requires interview process and submission of portfolio.

description.div: Conduct research and evaluate the findings to develop and present an integrated marketing communications strategy and creative materials for a multimedia advertising and public relations campaign needed by a client. Learn and apply basic business concepts involved in a working ad agency startup. Application of knowledge, experience, and skills learned in previous courses to a new situation.

notes.div: ADPR 433/833 has individual and team projects.

description.div: Visual and graphic design as applied to the corporate environments of advertising and public relations. Print and electronic design principles, strategies and elements using traditional and new digital technologies. Development of creative materials for actual clients, corporate identities, electronic presentations, professional creative portfolios, non-traditional resumes, and World Wide Web (WWW) sites.
A study of the digital communication landscape. Course explores how various channels of digital communication can be used to analyze audiences, connect with them and ultimately build brands.

Content and discussions on global issues affecting the public relations profession, the professional, the specialized practices, and the engagement of stakeholders simultaneously at home and at transnational levels.

Global advertising and communication. Cultural, economic, political and social differences that affect advertising strategy and execution in foreign markets. Advertising a USA product or service in the global market.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing and nine hours selected from 300- and 400-level ADPR courses and/or ADPR 207; permission required.

notes.div: Requires interview process and submission of portfolio.

description.div: Conduct research and evaluate the findings to develop and present an integrated marketing communications strategy and creative materials for a nationally competitive advertising and public relations campaign for a national client.

The alternative and advanced methods of communicating a message, a need, a perception or attitude. Creative storytelling and problem-solving, critique and analysis, and how to creatively communicate with strategic thinking and design.

Philosophies and theories that underlie the discipline and profession of public relations. The critical and supportive perspectives used to gain insight into the history and direction of public relations.
Multimedia tools in advertising, public relations, direct marketing, and sales promotion. Promotional writing, publications development, and media relations.

course.title: Crisis Management in Corporations and Nonprofits

description.div: Role of public relations in prevention of crises, response to crises, and recovery from crises. How to preempt, prepare for and respond to corporate, nonprofit and government sector crises from a public relations perspective.

Communication strategies and tactics using interactive media. Exploration of interactiveâ€™s role in strategic communications, user experience, information architecture, interactive design and development using current web technologies.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and either ADPR 283 or BRDC 228.

description.div: Analysis and preparation of radio and television commercials and announcements in terms of content and production techniques. Development of structure and functions of the broadcast advertising media. Regulations, responsibilities, audience analysis, and promotion.
Issues in sports media relations and integrated marketing communications. Background of the unpredictable nature of the sports industry and the relationships with its various publics and the media.
Key theories related to the study of social media, important social media monitoring and management practices, and advertising/PR opportunities on the most popular social and mobile media platforms.

notes.div: ADPR/ARTP 480/880 is a study abroad course that includes four days on campus in Lincoln and two and one-half weeks in Japan. ADPR/ARTP 480/880 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Test and hone visual literacy skills in a foreign country. Observe, analyze, and interpret visual information without the aid of text in the native Japanese language. Sharpen perceptual and analytical skills through daily drawing, writing, and photography in Japan. Increase global awareness through analysis of an issue.

notes.div: Experience the actual research process and produce a report.

description.div: Research in the planning, development and evaluation of advertising. The research process, use of secondary sources of information and how to analyze data from these sources. The planning and execution of primary research. Survey techniques.

Fundamentals of direct advertising, data base building and management, the economics of the industry, development and testing of effective creative materials, product selection and pricing, telemarketing, business to business direct advertising, lead-generating programs, the use of electronic and print media in the direct advertising mix and fund-raising for worthy causes.
How to improve individual portfolios of creative work and execute a variety of creative pieces that demonstrate improvement in their collections.

The managerial philosophy, techniques, and processes in advertising. Organizational structures, integrated marketing communications, strategic planning, marketing planning, advertising planning, advertising research, budgeting, and decision paradigms.

prerequisite.div: For ADPR majors: ADPR 283; Junior standing for BRDC majors.

description.div: Techniques for print and electronic media sales and promotion. Rate structures, legal requirements, and social and economic effects.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing and nine hours selected from ADPR 207 or from 300- or 400- level ADPR electives; permission required.

description.div: Conduct research and evaluate the findings to develop and present an integrated marketing communications strategy and creative materials for a multimedia advertising and public relations campaign needed by a client. Application of knowledge, experience, and skills learned in previous courses to a new situation.

notes.div: ADPR 491/891 may beÂ repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different. 12 hours max special topics hours at all levels (100, 200, 300, 400) per degree.

description.div: Topics vary each term.

notes.div: A maximum of 3 hours will be accepted toward the degree.

description.div:
Advertising- or Public Relations-related internships, paid or unpaid, will provide students with an opportunity to enhance their professional skills while contributing meaningful work and expanding their career networks.
Â Â Â Â Â Â·Â Â Â Â Â 1 hour of credit requires 100 hours of work during the term.
Â Â Â Â Â Â·Â Â Â Â Â 2 hours of credit require 200 hours of work during the term.
Â Â Â Â Â Â·Â Â Â Â Â 3 hours of credit require 300 hours of work during the term.

course.title: Independent Study in Advertising and Public Relations

prerequisite.div: For candidates with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications.

course.title: Strategic Communications: Advertising Issues and Strategies

description.div: Seminar for graduate students who do not have the equivalent of an undergraduate degree in advertising. Business of advertising and promotion, and the processes and planning involved in strategic promotional communication. Current issues and strategies faced by advertising practitioners, the importance of branding, integrated marketing communications and promotion. Creation of a strategic marketing plan.

Research in the planning, development and evaluation of advertising. The research process, use of secondary sources of information and how to analyze data from these sources. The planning and execution of primary research. Survey techniques.

The managerial philosophy, techniques, and processes in advertising. Organizational structures, integrated marketing communications, strategic planning, marketing planning, advertising planning, advertising research, budgeting, and decision paradigms.
Course may be repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different. Topic varies each semester.

prerequisite.div: Completion of at least two thirds of required coursework (24 hours) and Memorandum of Courses filed

description.div: Capstone course in the Integrated Media Communications (IMC) specialization.Â Reflect on different theories and concepts and apply thoseÂ theories and concepts to real-life examples and professional goals in a final paper and presentation to faculty and peers.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; ADPR major; candidate for degree.

notes.div: All seniors must complete an exit interview to remain eligible for graduation. ADPR 98 uses Blackboard. Pass/No Pass only.

description.div: Appropriate career-related announcements, activities, and responsibilities.
